title: P05-1056

sentences.text: Sentence boundary detection in speech is important for enriching speech recognition output , making it easier for humans to read and downstream modules to process .

In previous work , we have developed hidden Markov model -LRB- HMM -RRB- and maximum entropy -LRB- Maxent -RRB- classifiers that integrate textual and prosodic knowledge sources for detecting sentence boundaries .
In this paper , we evaluate the use of a conditional random field -LRB- CRF -RRB- for this task and relate results with this model to our prior work .
We evaluate across two corpora -LRB- conversational telephone speech and broadcast news speech -RRB- on both human transcriptions and speech recognition output .

In general , our CRF model yields a lower error rate than the HMM and Max-ent models on the NIST sentence boundary detection task in speech , although it is interesting to note that the best results are achieved by three-way voting among the classifiers .
This probably occurs because each model has different strengths and weaknesses for modeling the knowledge sources .

summary: Sentence boundary detection in speech is important for enriching speech recognition output , making it easier for humans to read and downstream modules to process . In previous work , we have developed hidden Markov model -LRB- HMM -RRB- and maximum entropy -LRB- Maxent -RRB- classifiers that integrate textual and prosodic knowledge sources for detecting sentence boundaries . In this paper , we evaluate the use of a conditional random field -LRB- CRF -RRB- for this task and relate results with this model to our prior work . We evaluate across two corpora -LRB- conversational telephone speech and broadcast news speech -RRB- on both human transcriptions and speech recognition output . In general , our CRF model yields a lower error rate than the HMM and Max-ent models on the NIST sentence boundary detection task in speech , although it is interesting to note that the best results are achieved by three-way voting among the classifiers . This probably occurs because each model has different strengths and weaknesses for modeling the knowledge sources .

Predicate-is_important_for_enriching.label: is important for enriching
Predicate-is_important_for_enriching.description: This predicate indicates that the subject has a crucial role in enhancing or improving the object. It suggests that the subject plays a vital part in refining, augmenting, or adding value to the object, making it more comprehensive, accurate, or meaningful.

Predicate-developed.label: developed
Predicate-developed.description: Indicates that a concept or idea was brought to a more advanced or mature state through research, experimentation, or other means. The subject refers to the foundation or starting point from which development occurred, and the object represents the resulting outcome or product of this process.

Predicate-evaluate.label: evaluate
Predicate-evaluate.description: To evaluate means to assess or judge the quality, value, or significance of something based on certain criteria or standards. The subject performs this assessment by examining and analyzing the object, which can be a person, thing, idea, or concept.

Predicate-transcribe.label: transcribe
Predicate-transcribe.description: To transcribe means to convert or represent written or spoken information into a standardized format, often from one medium to another. This process involves capturing and interpreting the original content's structure, syntax, and semantics, then rendering it in a new form that can be easily read, understood, or processed by humans or machines.

Predicate-models.label: models
Predicate-models.description: The predicate 'models' represents a relationship where the subject (in this case, each model) is an instance or representation of the object (the knowledge sources). This connection suggests that the models are based on, derived from, or informed by the knowledge sources. In general, it implies a mapping or correspondence between the two entities.

Predicate-yields.label: yields
Predicate-yields.description: The predicate 'yields' indicates a relationship where the subject produces or generates an object, often implying that the subject's internal workings or processes result in the creation of the object.

Predicate-relate_results_with.label: relate results with
Predicate-relate_results_with.description: To connect or associate a set of outcomes or findings with an entity, concept, or method. This predicate indicates that the subject has generated or obtained results and is linking them to the object for further analysis, interpretation, or comparison.

skos:broader.label: has a broader term
skos:broader.description: The predicate 'has a broader term' indicates that the subject is a specific instance or example of a more general concept or category represented by the object. The relationship between the subject and object is one of instantiation, where the subject is a concrete realization of the abstract idea or class denoted by the object.
